abstract.p: Juan Montoya discusses winning Indianapolis 500 auto race (S)

block.p: The mean streets of New York managed to do what the track at Indianapolis Motor Speedway could not: slow down Juan Montoya, the winner of the 2000 Indy 500.
The mean streets of New York managed to do what the track at Indianapolis Motor Speedway could not: slow down Juan Montoya, the winner of the 2000 Indy 500.
Montoya, who so dominated the race on Sunday that he led for 167 of 200 laps, was an hour late yesterday for a press luncheon at Tavern on the Green because he was stuck in traffic.

At one point, Montoya, who average of 167.607 miles an hour at Indianpolis, considered the only mode of transportation that might possibly match his times, the subway, to get from Wall Street, where he visited the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, to the restaurant on Central Park West.

Montoya, who was the first driver from the Championship Auto Racing Teams to race at Indy since the 1996 split between CART and its rival, the Indy Racing League, thinks the two leagues ''should never have separated from the start.''

''Now, everyone is trying to build a fight between CART and I.R.L. and I don't think there is a fight there,'' Montoya said. ''We have two series championships and each are going in the same direction.''
